items.title: Live: European leaders 'will not leave' summit without Ukraine funding deal, EU chief says
items.standfirst: European Union leaders will not leave today's summit in Brussels without an agreement to finance Ukraine, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said on Thursday. Earlier that day, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky said no decision on frozen Russian assets would be "big problem" for Kyiv. Follow our liveblog for the latest updates.

items.title: EU leaders urged to use frozen Russian assets to fund Ukraine’s defence
items.standfirst: Pressure is growing on member states to back a €90bn loan for Kyiv ahead of a Brussels summitEurope live – latest updatesEuropean leaders are being urged to decide whether to use Russia’s frozen assets to fund Ukraine’s defence at a time of unprecedented pressure from the US.At a critical summit in Brussels on Thursday, EU leaders will be asked to make good on a promise to find urgently needed cash for Ukraine, with Kyiv under pressure to cede territory as Russia ekes out advances on the battlefield. Continue reading...
items.content: Pressure is growing on member states to back a €90bn loan for Kyiv ahead of a Brussels summitEurope live – latest updatesEuropean leaders are being urged to decide whether to use Russia’s frozen assets to fund Ukraine’s defence at a time of unprecedented pressure from the US.At a critical summit in Brussels on Thursday, EU leaders will be asked to make good on a promise to find urgently needed cash for Ukraine, with Kyiv under pressure to cede territory as Russia ekes out advances on the battlefield. items.title: US 'pressuring' EU not to use frozen Russian assets for Kyiv, Ukraine official says
items.standfirst: The Trump administration is seeking to discourage European countries from using frozen Russian assets to support Ukraine's war effort, a senior Ukrainian official said Wednesday, adding that President Volodymyr Zelensky would lobby Kyiv's European allies to tap the Russian assets at an EU summit in Brussels on Thursday.
items.content: The Trump administration is seeking to discourage European countries from using frozen Russian assets to support Ukraine's war effort, a senior Ukrainian official said Wednesday, adding that President Volodymyr Zelensky would lobby Kyiv's European allies to tap the Russian assets at an EU summit in Brussels on Thursday.

US Supports Taiwan Defense Under Law The sale includes artillery systems, anti-tank missiles, and spare parts for…

US Supports Taiwan Defense Under Law The sale includes artillery systems, anti-tank missiles, and spare parts for…

items.title: US announces massive package of arms sales to Taiwan valued at more than $10 billion
items.standfirst: The Trump administration has announced a massive package of arms sales to Taiwan valued at more than $10 billion that includes medium-range missiles, howitzers and drones, a move that is sure to infuriate China.
items.content: The Trump administration has announced a massive package of arms sales to Taiwan valued at more than $10 billion that includes medium-range missiles, howitzers and drones, a move that is sure to infuriate China.(Image credit: Doug Mills)

items.title: Trump Approves Largest US Arms Sale to Taiwan Amid China Tensions
items.standfirst: The $11 billion deal includes rocket launchers, howitzers, and drones to boost Taipei's asymmetric defenses.
items.content: The $11 billion deal includes rocket launchers, howitzers, and drones to boost Taipei's asymmetric defenses.

items.title: China tells US to 'immediately' stop arming Taiwan after Washington approves arms package
items.standfirst: China told the United States on Thursday to "immediately stop" arming Taiwan after Taipei said Washington had authorised a $11 billion weapons package to the island. Approved by the State Department but awaiting congressional approval, the sale would take effect in about a month, according to Taiwan's Defense Ministry.
items.content: China told the United States on Thursday to "immediately stop" arming Taiwan after Taipei said Washington had authorised a $11 billion weapons package to the island. Approved by the State Department but awaiting congressional approval, the sale would take effect in about a month, according to Taiwan's Defense Ministry.

clusters.title: Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent Peter Arnett, who reported on Vietnam and Gulf wars, has died
clusters.neutral_headline: Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent Peter Arnett has died

items.title: Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent Peter Arnett, who reported on Vietnam and Gulf wars, has died
Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent Peter Arnett has died
items.standfirst: Peter Arnett, the Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter who spent decades dodging bullets and bombs to bring the world eyewitness accounts of war from Vietnam to Iraq, has died. He was 91.
items.content: Peter Arnett, the Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter who spent decades dodging bullets and bombs to bring the world eyewitness accounts of war from Vietnam to Iraq, has died. He was 91.(Image credit: AP)

items.title: Peter Arnett, Pulitzer Prize-winning war correspondent, dies at 91
items.standfirst: Peter Arnett, the Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent who covered the Vietnam and Gulf wars, has died. He was 91.
items.content: Peter Arnett, the Pulitzer Prize-winning correspondent who covered the Vietnam and Gulf wars, has died. He was 91.

items.title: Peter Arnett, Pulitzer prize-winner who reported on Vietnam and Gulf wars, dies aged 91
items.standfirst: Arnett won 1966 Pulitzer Prize for international reporting for his Vietnam War coverage for the Associated PressPeter Arnett, the Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter who spent decades dodging bullets and bombs to bring the world eyewitness accounts of war from the rice paddies of Vietnam to the deserts of Iraq, has died at 91.Arnett, who won the 1966 Pulitzer Prize for international reporting for his Vietnam War coverage for the Associated Press, died on Wednesday in Newport Beach, California, and was surrounded by friends and family, said his son Andrew Arnett. He had entered hospice on Saturday while suffering from prostate cancer. Continue reading...
items.content: Arnett won 1966 Pulitzer Prize for international reporting for his Vietnam War coverage for the Associated PressPeter Arnett, the Pulitzer Prize-winning reporter who spent decades dodging bullets and bombs to bring the world eyewitness accounts of war from the rice paddies of Vietnam to the deserts of Iraq, has died at 91.Arnett, who won the 1966 Pulitzer Prize for international reporting for his Vietnam War coverage for the Associated Press, died on Wednesday in Newport Beach, California, and was surrounded by friends and family, said his son Andrew Arnett. He had entered hospice on Saturday while suffering from prostate cancer. Continue reading...

items.title: President Trump delivers year-end address to the nation | Special Report
items.standfirst: President Trump delivered a prime-time address from the White House on Wednesday night, touting the administration's actions during the first 11 months of his second term and outlining his goals for the next three years. CBS News' Norah O'Donnell anchors a special report.
items.content: President Trump delivered a prime-time address from the White House on Wednesday night, touting the administration's actions during the first 11 months of his second term and outlining his goals for the next three years. CBS News' Norah O'Donnell anchors a special report.

items.title: Trump claims he's brought down prices, touts military bonuses in year-end address
items.standfirst: President Trump's speech Wednesday night looked back on his first year and ahead to the next three. He touted new military bonuses, his tariffs and economic policies in a brief address.
items.content: President Trump's speech Wednesday night looked back on his first year and ahead to the next three. He touted new military bonuses, his tariffs and economic policies in a brief address.

items.title: Trump touts first year as success amid economic unease in White House address
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump gave an address at the White House on Wednesday, attempting to cast his first year back in office as a success, deflecting concerns about the cost of living and offering few new policy details as he looked ahead to the 2026 midterm elections.
items.content: US President Donald Trump gave an address at the White House on Wednesday, attempting to cast his first year back in office as a success, deflecting concerns about the cost of living and offering few new policy details as he looked ahead to the 2026 midterm elections.

items.title: Early analysis, key takeaways from Trump's year-end address to nation
items.standfirst: President Trump addressed the nation from the White House on Wednesday night in a speech looking back on the first 11 months of his second term. Political strategists Joel Payne and Kevin Sheridan join with analysis. Then, CBS News chief White House correspondent Nancy Cordes joins to unpack Mr. Trump's remarks further.
items.content: President Trump addressed the nation from the White House on Wednesday night in a speech looking back on the first 11 months of his second term. Political strategists Joel Payne and Kevin Sheridan join with analysis. Then, CBS News chief White House correspondent Nancy Cordes joins to unpack Mr. Trump's remarks further.

items.title: How to watch Trump's prime-time address to the nation

items.content: President Trump gave a year-end address to the nation on Wednesday, focusing on his economic policies and immigration.

items.title: Trump touts policies in year-end address
items.standfirst: President Trump delivered remarks Wednesday night looking back at his first year back in office. Nancy Cordes reports.
items.content: President Trump delivered remarks Wednesday night looking back at his first year back in office. Nancy Cordes reports.

items.title: Trump insists on the US economy's strength in address to nation
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump used a prime-time address from the White House to play down public anxiety about the US economy, insisting it is on the mend despite rising inflation, slowing job growth and growing voter frustration ahead of the 2026 midterm elections. Follow our liveblog to see how the speech unfolded.

clusters.title: Venezuela denounces Trump's order for ship blockade as 'warmongering threats'
clusters.neutral_headline: What action is Trump taking against Venezuela’s oil industry

items.title: Venezuela denounces Trump's order for ship blockade as 'warmongering threats'
items.standfirst: It comes a week after the US seized an oil tanker off the country's coast, intensifying pressure on Nicolás Maduro.
items.content: It comes a week after the US seized an oil tanker off the country's coast, intensifying pressure on Nicolás Maduro.

items.title: Trump orders blockade of 'sanctioned oil tankers' into Venezuela, ramping up pressure on Maduro
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump on Tuesday ordered a “blockade” of all sanctioned oil tankers traveling to and from Venezuela, marking Washington’s latest effort to intensify pressure on Nicolás Maduro’s government by targeting its primary source of revenue. How the blockade would be enforced remains unclear, including whether Trump would again rely on the Coast Guard to intercept vessels, as he did last week, even as the administration has already deployed thousands of troops and nearly a dozen warships - including an aircraft carrier - to the region. Author and journalist Ioan Grillo shares his insights.
items.content: US President Donald Trump on Tuesday ordered a “blockade” of all sanctioned oil tankers traveling to and from Venezuela, marking Washington’s latest effort to intensify pressure on Nicolás Maduro’s government by targeting its primary source of revenue. How the blockade would be enforced remains unclear, including whether Trump would again rely on the Coast Guard to intercept vessels, as he did last week, even as the administration has already deployed thousands of troops and nearly a dozen warships - including an aircraft carrier - to the region. Author and journalist Ioan Grillo shares his insights.

items.title: What action is Trump taking against Venezuela’s oil industry?
items.standfirst: The US president wants a blockade of oil tankers under sanctions to stop them entering and leaving VenezuelaAnalysis: Maduro says the real reason for Trump’s fixation is oil – is he right?Donald Trump has intensified pressure on Venezuela’s president, Nicolas Maduro, and his government in a major escalation aimed at the country’s main source of income: the oil industry.The White House called for a blockade on all Venezuelan oil exports one week after the US seized an oil tanker off the the country’s coast in what Maduro called “an act of international piracy”. Continue reading...
items.content: The US president wants a blockade of oil tankers under sanctions to stop them entering and leaving VenezuelaAnalysis: Maduro says the real reason for Trump’s fixation is oil – is he right?Donald Trump has intensified pressure on Venezuela’s president, Nicolas Maduro, and his government in a major escalation aimed at the country’s main source of income: the oil industry.The White House called for a blockade on all Venezuelan oil exports one week after the US seized an oil tanker off the the country’s coast in what Maduro called “an act of international piracy”. Continue reading...

items.title: Trump orders blockade of 'sanctioned oil tankers' bound for Venezuela
items.standfirst: President Donald Trump announced Tuesday that the US will impose a blockade on all “sanctioned oil tankers” entering or leaving Venezuela, dramatically escalating his administration’s campaign against President Nicolás Maduro. The move follows the recent seizure of an oil tanker off Venezuela’s coast and a growing US military buildup in the region. France24 International Affairs commentator Douglas Herbert shares his insights.
items.content: President Donald Trump announced Tuesday that the US will impose a blockade on all “sanctioned oil tankers” entering or leaving Venezuela, dramatically escalating his administration’s campaign against President Nicolás Maduro. The move follows the recent seizure of an oil tanker off Venezuela’s coast and a growing US military buildup in the region. France24 International Affairs commentator Douglas Herbert shares his insights.

clusters.title: Rob and Michele Reiner’s cause of death released by medical examiner
clusters.neutral_headline: Rob and Michele Reiner’s cause of death released by medical examiner

items.title: Rob and Michele Reiner’s cause of death released by medical examiner
items.standfirst: The Reiners’ bodies were discovered on Sunday at their home in Los Angeles. Their son Nick was later arrested and charged with two counts of first-degree murder and has since appeared in courtThe Los Angeles County Medical Examiner has released reports stating the cause of death of the film director Rob Reiner and his wife, the photographer Michele Singer Reiner.Both are listed on the organisation’s website with the cause given as “multiple sharp force injuries” and “homicide” stated as the manner of death. The date of death, which had been the subject of some speculation, is given as Sunday 14 December. Continue reading...
items.content: The Reiners’ bodies were discovered on Sunday at their home in Los Angeles. Their son Nick was later arrested and charged with two counts of first-degree murder and has since appeared in courtThe Los Angeles County Medical Examiner has released reports stating the cause of death of the film director Rob Reiner and his wife, the photographer Michele Singer Reiner.Both are listed on the organisation’s website with the cause given as “multiple sharp force injuries” and “homicide” stated as the manner of death. The date of death, which had been the subject of some speculation, is given as Sunday 14 December. Continue reading...

items.content: Nick Reiner​ appeared in court on Wednesday on two counts of murder in the killing of his parents, Rob Reiner and Michele Singer Reiner.

items.title: Farmers head to Brussels to protest EU-Mercosur treaty as European leaders meet
items.standfirst: Thousands of European farmers are converging on Brussels on Thursday to protest against the EU-Mercosur treaty as European leaders meet for a summit. Protesters are worried about the prospect of an influx of South American products into the bloc and the reform of agricultural subsidies.

items.title: French court finds ‘twisted’ anaesthetist guilty of killing 12 patients
items.standfirst: Former top medic described as ‘Dr Death’ by prosecutors poisoned 30 people ranging in age from four to 89A French anaesthetist described by prosecutors as “Dr Death” has been found guilty of intentionally poisoning 30 patients and killing 12 over almost a decade as a top medic.Frédéric Péchier, 53, once seen by colleagues as a “star anaesthetist”, was sentenced to life in prison on Thursday after state prosecutors said he was “one of the biggest criminals in the history of the French legal system”. Continue reading...

Continue reading...

items.title: UK inflation falls sharply to 3.2% amid slowdown in food price rises
items.standfirst: Drop in November annual rate adds to case for Bank of England cut to interest rates on ThursdayAnalysis: Inflation drop makes Bank of England early Christmas present to Reeves almost a certaintyBusiness live – latest updatesUK inflation fell by more than expected in November to the lowest level in eight months amid a slowdown in food prices, clearing the way for the Bank of England to cut interest rates on Thursday.In a crunch week for the economy, the Office for National Statistics said the rate as measured by the consumer prices index eased to 3.2% last month from a reading of 3.6% in October. City economists had forecast a modest drop to 3.5%. Continue reading...

items.content: A filing states that the crew of the Army Black Hawk helicopter failed to establish and maintain proper and safe visual separation with a regional American Eagle flight that was approaching Reagan National Airport near Washington, D.C.

items.title: US government admits negligence in helicopter-plane collision that killed 67
items.standfirst: Official response to lawsuit filed by victims’ relatives admits FAA and army failures played role in Washington DC crashThe US government admitted Wednesday that the Federal Aviation Administration and the army played a role in causing the collision in January between an airliner and a Black Hawk helicopter near the nation’s capital, killing 67 people in the deadliest crash on American soil in more than two decades.The official response to the first lawsuit filed by one of the victims’ families said that the government is liable in the crash partly because the air traffic controller violated procedures about when to rely on pilots to maintain visual separation that night. Plus, the filing said, the army helicopter pilots’ “failure to maintain vigilance so as to see and avoid” the airline jet makes the government liable. Continue reading...
items.content: Official response to lawsuit filed by victims’ relatives admits FAA and army failures played role in Washington DC crashThe US government admitted Wednesday that the Federal Aviation Administration and the army played a role in causing the collision in January between an airliner and a Black Hawk helicopter near the nation’s capital, killing 67 people in the deadliest crash on American soil in more than two decades.The official response to the first lawsuit filed by one of the victims’ families said that the government is liable in the crash partly because the air traffic controller violated procedures about when to rely on pilots to maintain visual separation that night. Plus, the filing said, the army helicopter pilots’ “failure to maintain vigilance so as to see and avoid” the airline jet makes the government liable. Continue reading...

clusters.title: US Senate confirms Jared Isaacman as NASA chief amid budget cuts and moon race
clusters.neutral_headline: US Senate confirms Jared Isaacman as NASA chief amid budget cuts and moon race

items.title: US Senate confirms Jared Isaacman as NASA chief amid budget cuts and moon race
items.standfirst: The US Senate has confirmed billionaire private astronaut Jared Isaacman as NASA administrator, installing a strong advocate of Mars missions to lead the space agency as it faces deep budget cuts and intensifying competition with China to return humans to the Moon.
items.content: The US Senate has confirmed billionaire private astronaut Jared Isaacman as NASA administrator, installing a strong advocate of Mars missions to lead the space agency as it faces deep budget cuts and intensifying competition with China to return humans to the Moon.

items.title: Jared Isaacman, billionaire who's flown with SpaceX, confirmed to lead NASA
items.standfirst: President Trump withdrew Isaacman's nomination for NASA administrator in April, before nominating him again in November.
items.content: President Trump withdrew Isaacman's nomination for NASA administrator in April, before nominating him again in November.

clusters.title: Trump installs partisan plaques for past presidents at White House
clusters.neutral_headline: Trump installs partisan plaques for past presidents at White House

items.title: Trump installs partisan plaques for past presidents at White House
items.standfirst: President Trump added plaques with disparaging comments about Biden and Obama on a "Presidential Walk of Fame" at the White House.
items.content: President Trump added plaques with disparaging comments about Biden and Obama on a "Presidential Walk of Fame" at the White House.

items.title: Disparaging plaques for Biden, Obama appear in Trump's White House 'Walk of Fame'
items.standfirst: US President Donald Trump has added partisan and subjective plaques to his White House presidential "Walk of Fame", taking personal swipes at his predecessors Joe Biden and Barack Obama and repeating false claims about his 2020 election defeat.
items.content: US President Donald Trump has added partisan and subjective plaques to his White House presidential "Walk of Fame", taking personal swipes at his predecessors Joe Biden and Barack Obama and repeating false claims about his 2020 election defeat.

clusters.title: Warner Bros. rejects Paramount's bid, accuses it of 'consistently misleading' shareholders
clusters.neutral_headline: Warner Bros. Urges Investors to Reject Paramount

items.title: Warner Bros. rejects Paramount's bid, accuses it of 'consistently misleading' shareholders
items.standfirst: Warner Brothers Discovery has rejected Paramount Skydance's hostile takeover bid, saying it carries many risks and is inferior to Netflix's offer. The company's board said the Ellison family that controls Paramount "consistently misled" them about guarantees as it urged shareholders not to sell their stocks. Plus, as oil prices rise following US President Donald Trump's order to blockade oil tankers in and out of Venezuela, we take a look at just how central oil is to the South American country's economy.
items.content: Warner Brothers Discovery has rejected Paramount Skydance's hostile takeover bid, saying it carries many risks and is inferior to Netflix's offer. The company's board said the Ellison family that controls Paramount "consistently misled" them about guarantees as it urged shareholders not to sell their stocks. Plus, as oil prices rise following US President Donald Trump's order to blockade oil tankers in and out of Venezuela, we take a look at just how central oil is to the South American country's economy.

items.title: Warner Bros. Urges Investors to Reject Paramount
items.standfirst: Warner Bros. Discovery is pressing shareholders to oppose Paramount Skydance’s hostile takeover offer, maintaining support for its original agreement with Netflix. Bloomberg’s Michelle Davis breaks down the latest developments with Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)
items.content: Warner Bros. Discovery is pressing shareholders to oppose Paramount Skydance’s hostile takeover offer, maintaining support for its original agreement with Netflix. Bloomberg’s Michelle Davis breaks down the latest developments with Caroline Hyde on “Bloomberg Tech.” (Source: Bloomberg)

clusters.title: Jack Smith defends his prosecutions of Trump in closed-door session in Congress
clusters.neutral_headline: Jack Smith defends Trump prosecutions in testimony to Congress

items.title: Jack Smith defends his prosecutions of Trump in closed-door session in Congress
items.standfirst: The former Justice Department special counsel told the House Judiciary Committee that his team developed "proof beyond a reasonable doubt" that Trump took part in a criminal scheme to overturn the 2020 election.
items.content: The former Justice Department special counsel told the House Judiciary Committee that his team developed "proof beyond a reasonable doubt" that Trump took part in a criminal scheme to overturn the 2020 election.(Image credit: Drew Angerer)

items.title: Jack Smith defends Trump prosecutions in testimony to Congress
items.standfirst: The former US Special Counsel is facing questions about his two defunct criminal investigations into President Donald Trump.
items.content: The former US Special Counsel is facing questions about his two defunct criminal investigations into President Donald Trump.
